Euthanasia and suicide are something which every person should have the right to.

 Euthanasia and suicide are both illegal. Should they be?

On suicide:
 
 If a person tries and succeeds, there can be no punishment for it.

 On euthanasia:

I agree that euthenasia and suicide should not be prosecuted against (i.e. illegal). To my knowledge suicide isn't in England...

 Euthenasia ia a slightly differnt matter. Many people who 'want' to do this do it because they see themselves as a burden on their families or the hospital. if i tried to kill myself, and ended up in jail, i would rather die than 'dance' with a guy named bubba 24/7.

There are various issues with euthanasia. It's not just a case of saying it should be legal or not. If someone is terminally ill, elderly and in pain then I think it should be allowed but only if that person can make a rational decision that they want to die. 
 
 However, it could lead to people feeling pressured to use euthanasia if they feel they are a burden on their family. What about checking up on doctors? How can you check that every single case of euthanasia has been carried out with consent? Doctors could just use without consent just to free up beds if they know they won't be found out. 
 
 Then theres the different types of euthanasia like active, passive, voluntary & involuntary. Which ones are made legal? It's a pretty big topic to think about.
i believe THAT person should decide whether he or she should be 'put to sleep' or not. if this person is unable to, the family should decide.

I understand the views towards ones right to harm or kill themselves, but I also see some points in the against side.
 
 If legal, is seems logical the suicide could be more common. This would make the rest of society a tad more gloomy to say the least.
 
 Also, the right of someone to kill themselves opens up thought of the right of people to kill others. Even if you and I do not see a logical jump, some people would.
 
 Most importantly, many feel that when people commin suicide they are reacting to temperary feelings. If supressed at the moment (for example, by the threat of getting punished by cops if they are found to fail or just by a more negative feeling about suicide created by a society where is is illegal and frowned upon) then many feel they will later regret even considering it.
 
 I think the issue a lot of people have with suicide being legal isn't the actual ability for someone to kill themselves if they really wanted to, but the implecations and effects that would have on other aspect of life.
i am looking at the idea of 'putting to sleep' and person in pain. someone that has an incurable disease and has very little time to live.

 I think that anyone who wants to die should have the right, but I also think that they should have to consult with a physician beforehand. The physician would be able to assess the chance of survival for the patient, and discuss other ways that the pain could be managed. If the patient still determines they want to die, then they should have the right to. 
 
 
 i think of every suicide represents a failure in society the failure to reach out and help those who need it.

 
 Exactly.
 
 
People who want to commit suicide should get help first, because often suicidal tendency is a result of mental turmoil (depression, loneliness) and death is not what you need

 
 But unfortunately, most suicides are not calculated events. They occur almost spontaneously. Such-and-such happens and the person decides that they don't want to live anymore. Sure, we can say that people should get help first, but many times, they don't even think about help.

Jim, you are right, most suicides are not calculated events,but that's the problem; people don't think it through 
 the top 8 causes of suicide are: 
 1.Death of a spouse 
 2.Divorce
 3 Marital difficulties 
 4.Trouble with the law
 5.Death of a loved one
 6.Serious Illness
 7.Loss of a job
 8.Retirement
 So, suicide is more or less predictable. 
 It's like When you're hungry you automatically think of Red Lobster or Burger King. Why is that? Because they advertise! They bombard your mind with images of perfect food that you never get. So when your tummy rumbles those images scream aloud in your subconcious.
 Why don't we advertise compassion that way? 
 If we did, people would think about help the instant they think of killing themselves. They would say: I'm confused, miserable, & lonely but I know where I can go to solve this problem.

I for one do not think suicide should be legal. Honestly, how many suicidal people ever consider going to see a psychiatrist? The scenario doesn't even make sense. "Oh, I've done all I can do. hrm.....Do we solely live for others
 so that they might not be hurt,
 and they will do the same for us?
 Is that the pact that is broken
 and makes suicide illegal,
 that we hurt someone in taking our lives
 no never harm ourselves for once dead
 we feel no pain,
 right?
 
 
 a sarcastic reply to suicide being illegal is the following...mostly saying that fine, so suicide is illegal...so is living? living = death....we're all hopelessly guilty. come and get us government, and 'lawfully' kill us.
 
 So taking my life is illegal?
 Is me throwing out my trash illegal?
 I am my own trash,
 if I deem me so.
 Go ahead, convict the dead,
 Sentence all the living too.
 
 Your breathing now
 assures your death.
 So lock us all in jail
 but hold onto the key,
 who knows where our minds should wander.
 Well I left open the door,
 so come and join us.
 Or maybe, you'd rather
 condemn us all for not killing now...
 and assisting their inevitable end?
 Life isn't a law.
 They have the right to kill,
 you do not.
 they took that right for their own,
 and you stood staring, indifferent and dead.
 
 There is no good,
 only shame.
 Wear it like a belt around your waist,
 keeping up your pants.
 Don't tie it to the rafters
 then jump into space.
 If you don't breathe
 it can't choke the breath out of you.
 If you don't die,
 you can't live.
 
 Don't condemn the dead,
 condemn the living.

 It is a matter of having compassion on someone. It is not normal to want to die. It is a lack of compassion that says, okay then go ahead.

If he is unstable and has difficulties to distinguish right from wrong it's just the same case as commiting murder.

 I find a difference between suicide and murder. Murder is the killing of one indivisual. Murder is not commited to a willful and desiring of death person. It instead is done to someone who does not wish to die (in most cases).
 Suicide on the other hand is done by your choice. You want to end your life and if thats truly what you want to do then its not murder. Murder has two parties involved. The murderers and the victims. Suicide has one person involved.
 
 
Many people tried to kill themselves unsuccessfuly and continued living a great life. If your life sucks now, it could become better in the future. You never know.

He believes, as I do, that God put him here for a reason and he will not thwart the plans of God by trying to duck out early. He will wait for God to take his life.

 My arguments are supported by a fundamental belief that human life is precious. If a person wants to die. That is not normal. Even if it has to do with extensive suffering. The issue is that a society that condones suicide is a society that does not care about its people.
 
 When a person WANTS to die we, as a society, consider it abnormal and have, therefore, an obligation to assist that person in not wanting to die. If we condone suicide it is a short hop to condoning mercy killing, then homicide in the name of mercy killing then flat out anarchy. 
 
 This is not some straw man argument but is based on our ideals as a society. If life ends here, if there is nothing more then nothing matters and we might as well kill each other. That is where this mercy killing philosophy comes from. If however, there is something beyond then human life is precious and should be protected by society.

My arguments are supported by a fundamental belief that human life is precious. If a person wants to die. That is not normal. Even if it has to do with extensive suffering. The issue is that a society that condones suicide is a society that does not care about its people.

 A society that cares enough for its people to let them end their suffering is a society that cares about its people. 
 
 
When a person WANTS to die we, as a society, consider it abnormal and have, therefore, an obligation to assist that person in not wanting to die. If we condone suicide it is a short hop to condoning mercy killing, then homicide in the name of mercy killing then flat out anarchy. 
 
 
 No its not a short hop. Its a huge hop. There is a big difference between wanting to die and killing yourself and not wanting to die and having someone else kill you. 
 When a person is in pain that will only end in death it is natural for a person to long for that death.
 
 
This is not some straw man argument but is based on our ideals as a society. If life ends here, if there is nothing more then nothing matters and we might as well kill each other. That is where this mercy killing philosophy comes from. If however, there is something beyond then human life is precious and should be protected by society.

 So what if there is something more on the other side? How does this add to your argument on not allowing mercy killing?
 
 We put dogs to sleep who are living in such pain. Why not do the same to people and respect their wishes?

When you have been unable to move for weeks and weeks in soaring pain in which you know will only stop when you die, I think its perfectly ok to want to die. Yes its natural for you to want the pain to stop.

 The reason you must include the mentally handicapped in your argument is that it is a logical extension of "euthanizing" those in pain. 
 
 As for my personal beliefs, The laws of the US were grounded in moral laws. Laws exist for no other reason than to provide a common basis upon which to decide what is right and worng, hence moral. There must be an absolute idea of right and wrong. Life is precious. This is the moral foundation for laws such as no murder, no suicide and therefore no euthanasia for humans. It is a fundamental belief of all societies that human life is of great value. If we cheapen it by saying that pain is reason enough to end it then we subvert the very foundation of our society.

 you see, giving the choice to some but not all is discriminatory. (to discriminate means to differ between groups).  The number of references to a "self" in these statements are 8...in just three sentences. Suicide, in most cases, is a very self-centered act. Before the issue of whether it is legal or not, we should consider the act. A selfish, self-centered person is concerned with only the self. When a person becomes too caught up in a world that has been created to revolve around yours truly, they tend to be very lonely people who are unable to have a relationship. I know a few depressed people who fit this description, and I know that as long as they care about only themselves, they will never know love or hope. What is life without reason and something other than yourself to care about? Nothing. This is what brings about thoughts of suicide. On the issue of legality, what's it matter? It's not like the person commiting the act will be punished. If there were a way to stop suicide simply by keeping it illegal, I would be all for keeping it illegal. I don't believe self-centered people should be allowed a cowards way out. I'd rather teach the unhappy how to be happy first.
 
 As for terminal illness, I suppose it's an aspect of life I'd have to live through. I'd hope, though, that I could stay strong and live as long as I can for those I love.

As for terminal illness, I suppose it's an aspect of life I'd have to live through. I'd hope, though, that I could stay strong and live as long as I can for those I love.
 
 
 Why must you live through it? Why not have mercy granted upon you by meants of euthansia?

Why must you live through it? Why not have mercy granted upon you by meants of euthansia?

 
 I mean that I'd have to experience terminal illness before I know for a fact that I would choose to die rather than live for those I love. I'd find a debate on this topic more interesting if someone who knows this reality were debating...but at that point, other things are possibly more important than whether they have the right to die or not. Again, I think someone with the true perspective of terminal illness could shed more insight on this issue.

 True and I agree. Although we are not arguing on whether someone should but rather if they should have the right to.

Greetings friends,
 
 I am new to these boards and I wish to add my own sentiment to this particular topic of debate.
 
 It is extremely difficult to argue a topic without attempting to a find the root or purpose for its existence. Without a 'philosophical' beginning, we are all really just stating opinions and butting heads. The only solution that has been presented thus far is that everyone has the right to do as they wish.
 
 I am nay in favor of suicide/euthanasia on the grounds that it is unethical, consequential, and just plain ignorant.
 
 Suicide is unethical. The human race's success as a species relies on our capability to learn and work together. The absence of a single member, particularily a juvenile one, holds great bearing on our present and future. Each individual is a human resource capable of great things if they so wish it. 
 
 Suicide has negative consequences on our environment. The act of suicide causes others pain, grief, uneeded hardship, and sends a negative message to others around the victim. By committing suicide, the family and friends of the selfish victim are torn apart. Their lives become a wreck as they try to determine what went wrong. They may become insecure and feel inadequate as parents and friends. In addition to their grief, they will also need to pay your '$5,000 minimum' burial expense. The victim may also become a role model for other's who wish to prematurely end their lives. One may also create unnecessary hazards and risks while attempting to commit suicide which may lead to the deaths of others.
 
 Suicide is just ignorant. Yes, those who seek to end their own lives are emmotionaly unstable and intellectually sterile. Unable to cope with their problems, which are typically trivial, they end their lives rather than to simply move on. The death of a loved one, getting dumped by a loved one, catching a serious STD, loss of a job, loss of material possessions, money, even a terminal illness. These are all trivial and could happen to anyone. The question is, what do you do when its your turn? If you don't believe in magic and miracles, it's probably time you started. Quit worrying about your problems and help others with theirs. If the illness is terminal, focus on love, joy, and fullfillment of what time is left.
 
 "Well, it's my body, I can do what I want with it!" It most certainly is your body, and unfortunately, you can do what you want with it. This means that everytime a nine-year-old is dumped by his girlfriend, he has an obligation to hang himself from the closet and it is perfectly okay, right? A guy decides to jump off of a bridge to commit suicide. Two police officers jump over to save him. He washes up on the shore and lives. The officers do not. You may think that this is stupid, but it happens. A guy shoots himself, dead center, in his forehead and lives....as a vegetable. No matter what you do, there is always a possibility for failure and you will always cause harm to someone else whether it be mental or physical.
 
 "Why is suicide illegal? That's so dumb!" Yea well, we as human beings can't bare to finish job you started, so we offer to throw you in jail. Consider it attempted murder on yourself.
 
 "What about euthanasia?" Alright, you are afraid or incapable of murdering yourself, so you want someone else to do it? Jeffrey Dalmer would have been happy to oblige. Oh, the pain, the pain... Get over it. If your only worrying about your pain, your not worrying about others' pain and you simply do not find value and love in life. If you did, the pain would be minimal.
 
 "How can you love life if your dying and in pain!!!" How can you ever not love life? New born babies, nursery rhymes, scribbling in coloring books, crayons, chicken noodle soup, spaghetti O's, Dopey from Snow White, puppies with waggly tails, girls with cooties, saturday morning cartoons, eating the marshmellows out of Lucky Charms, briefs with He-Man on them, Transformer action figures, your first kiss, your first... yea....There is just to much too appreciate, but if you don't try, you've already confined yourself to death.
 
 In the end, no matter how you look at it, you've caused more harm and suffering than you've prevented to yourself. You are not free. This is not a free country. Even if it is your body, your government owns you whether you like it or not. You are a resource, valuable or otherwise. You do not have the right to cause harm to yourself or your loved ones, and thus, you do not have the right to commit suicide.
 
 And that's my two cents.
 
 
 Thank you,
 Leviathan

[QUOTE=Striel]Euthanasia and suicide are something which every person should have the right to. 
 
 i think euthanasia and suicide should not be made legal.It is right to say that it is " My Body and My life".But to come to think of it the circumstances when such acts are thought of are more less than often those time when a person feels down and out with life,for whatever reason..he feels dejected and in such circumstances he is bound to make decisions which unfortunately enough he would'nt have the chance to regret..and most unfortunately enough live the life he has given up in haste.Death is not a solution to a problem..it should be tackled in a more mature manner.once euthanasia is legalised the time would not be far when it would be exploited and would take an evil shape, and moreso the life givers would become mere life takers..

Yes, it's a documentable fact.

Neither of them should be made legal. In fact, I believe that we need more public awareness as to the growing problem it is with the youth of today who think that everything bad happens to them and that life isn't living. There are several kids in my school (people I know, don't really hang around with them) who have tried to commit suicide or have come very close to doing it. It's a serious problem that affects not only the person that does it, as many are alluding to in this thread, but those around them as well. Think. How would you feel if your best friend, your spouse, your brother, your sister, your parent, commited suicide?

A short summary of the Dutch bill:
 Dutch bill 
 
 No, I don't think that doctors kill people in the Netherlands...
That's what they say they have to do, but I seriously doubt it. If I can find it, I'll find the article on it online......

From the link you gave me:
 
 
 
Cease treatment But there are other options open to doctors to end the suffering of a terminally ill patient. The doctor can decide to withhold or cease treatment if continuing treatment is pointless, and only serves to prolong pain and suffering. This can be done at the request of the patient, or if the patient is no longer capable of making conscious decisions, after consultation with the closest relatives. Nature is then allowed to take its course, and the patient will die, but it does not constitute euthanasia. 
 
 
 
 See? The Docter can decide to withold treatment if he decides it's pointless. I sure don't want some guy deciding whether or not he feel's like keeping me alive today.

The doctor can decide to withhold or cease treatment if continuing treatment is pointless, and only serves to prolong pain and suffering. This can be done at the request of the patient, or if the patient is no longer capable of making conscious decisions, after consultation with the closest relatives.

 He doesn't decide on his own; and you can always include in your last will that life preserving measures should be taken, so this case wouldn't happen anyway.
 I don't wanna convince in this matter and I certainly couldn't ever but let's stick to the facts.
Oops, didn't read the fine print. emoticon_emb

I haven't read much on this thread about religion. (I could have missed something.) Does not the Catholic Church hold that some eternal punishment will follow suicide?
 
 I personally believe suicide should be discouraged and that people with such tendencies need our help. It should not be illegal. There should however, be some way to extract payment for damages caused to other people's property during the implementation of the suicide...like damage to another vehicle when the suicide is committed by deliberately crashing into a bus, or the clean up costs of getting the blood and guts off the pavement when someone jumps from a building. We certainly can't let these people off scot-free.
 
 On euthanasia, if a person wrote, signed and recorded a "living will" while that person was of sound mind and body, stating their preference not to suffer a lingering death, they should be allowed to die at the hands of a euthanasianist, like Dr. Kervorkian. That would save the family and the country a lot of money and decrease the grief among us.
 
 (This has nothing to do with youth in Asia.) emoticon_xbye
